awd_titl_txt: TWC: TTP Option: Small: Open-Audit Voting Systems---Protocol Models and Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Open-audit cryptographic voting protocols enable the verification of election outcomes, independent of whether election officials or polling machines behave honestly. Many open-audit voting systems have been prototyped and deployed. The City of Takoma Park, MD held its 2009 and 2011 city elections using voting system Scantegrity. Systems with similar properties are being proposed for use in Victoria, Australia (the Pret a Voter system) and Travis County, Texas (the STAR-Vote system). 

This project obtains rigorous results on the properties of in-person voting protocols'-in particular the Scantegrity, Pret a Voter and STAR-Vote protocols. It further examines the properties of classes of in-person protocols and the limits to their achievement of desirable properties. It thus improves our understanding of the security properties of voting systems that are being used in real governmental elections.

The project proposes new protocols where voters and virtual observers use a peer network of untrusted computational assistants to improve protocol properties. It provides a software library for the development of open-audit voting systems.

por.por_cntn:
Research: The project made the following progress:

New Voting Protocols: We developed voting protocols for remote (internet) voting. Note that internet voting is not yet secure enough for use in any protocols where the vote needs to be secret. Thus, in particular, it is not yet secure enough for use in governmental elections. Our protocols improve on the security of existing ones, but do not solve all the problems in internet voting security.We developed:

  • Du-Vote, which eliminates the often-required assumption that voters trust general-purpose computers. Trust is distributed in Du-Vote between a simple hardware token issued to the voter, the voter?s computer, and a server run by election authorities.
  • Apollo, which provides protection against an attack where the voting computer uses the voter's credential, but casts a vote for a candidate other than the voter's choice. priv-Apollo is an enhancement of Apollo that provides more protection to the privacy of the vote when the voting machine is not trusted to protect it.

Protocol Properties and Proofs: We approached rigorous study from two perspectives:

  • Cryptographic Protocols: We developed election verifiability definitions, and applied them to the analysis of two versions of the popular Helios protocol, previously used for elections of the International Association of Cryptologic Research (IACR) and the Association of Computing Machinery (ACM).
  • Statistical Tabulation Audits: We developed a common framework for traditional risk-limiting polling audits as described by Stark, and computational Bayesian audits as described by Rivest. Our approach has the flexibility of computational Bayesian audits and the rigorous properties of risk-limiting audits. Our claims are rigorously supported.

Transition to Practice (TTP): We developed a software library for election tabulation audits, and expect that it will be used for tabulation audits in the November elections. Software written by us was used for the tabulation audit of the primary in Montgomery County, Ohio in May 2020. Additionally, we have integrated our new Athena approach into a version of the most widely-used software for election auditing, Arlo. All Python code is released as open source under the MIT license.

Outreach: PI Vora provided oral and written testimony on several occasions to the Maryland Legislature. She was co-chair for the annual conference of the Election Verification Network, which is a non-partisan group of election integrity experts, including academics, election officials and election integrity advocates. The software developed has been used for a real primary election audit in Montgomery County, Ohio. We have been working with The Brennan Center for Justice and non-partisan non-profit Verified Voting to communicate with election officials interested in doing election tabulation audits.

Modified by: Poorvi Vora
